SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name: Chris O. Atkings
Present Address: Ridgedale St.
Pioneer Address: Star Valley St.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? about 8, within 3 miles.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? All but two.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once a week or so, usually to borrow something or carry them mail.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Anytime—except bachelors, usually they came along on a Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Not much inviting—except to come whenever you can.

What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Anytime—usually leaving time to get home before dark.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Sure—anybody was always welcome anytime.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) "Sit—help yourself—if you came along at meal time."

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Maybe a cup of tea or coffee.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Usually someone stayed home.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Only one or two—very small ones.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. On June 8, 1912, a small bee was held on John Winfield's (G.W., 24.4). It was a coffee—about 25 turned out to clean land (all by hand) ready for planting.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

No—mostly bachelors—the places too small—that goes for the married couples.

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates. Yes—about 1934-5.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? In a way—at one time, we would agree to hold the next at one of the neighbors on a certain day—not always set definite days. (This is 1934 or 5)—no parties, etc. in early days.

8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

I live in Edenbridge S.D. - but because of its inaccessibility I never went there - (nothing doing anyhow) - my youngsters go to Hudson S.D. where we used to play special gatherings - But this school was not built until 1918.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

not much for us - from 1910 to 1922 if we went to any doings - it had to be very big - (brill)

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

I collect stamps - about 2,750 - also collect prehistoric signatures - 10 names of Indians in England - I also save (collect?) all the interesting (to children especially) covers of county gentle men's country guides & the like. Some day maybe I'll make a scrapbook. I have a collection of Indian stoneware - arrowheads - spear heads - etc., etc.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

Yes - made at the time from 1908 to 1930. I kept weather records for my own use (from about 1920 to 1928). I had kept the Dominion weather records for this district. Also actually diary from about 1908.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

I like to collect old things - I have a piece of the original Atlantic cable - laid by the "Great Western". I also have bottles from a house from a house being torn down about 1892 - often over 200 years old - some still exposed to air, etc., etc.

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

In the early days, folks seemed much more given to playing poker etc., today every one seems too busy chasing dollars - but of course there are more organized affairs in the villages & schools. In the early days, the only entertainments were visiting occasionally going to town (St. E. G.) once a month or so. We'd make up for it by playing poker etc. It was a rarity a bachelor place - we'd sometimes put a few bullets through his chimney, blow pipe - or if he wasn't home - stuff a trap or something down it. One trick was to sell a black cat skin to store keeper for $1.
